channel.title: SevenAtSevenSection1
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from SevenAtSevenSection1, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Italy makes a surprising discovery ahead of the Winter Olympics: dinosaur tracks
item.description: A nature photographer stumbled upon thousands of 210-million-year-old dinosaur tracks in Italy's central Alps, near where some Olympic skiing and snow...

item.title: Federal court says troops can stay in D.C., and hints at prolonged deployment
item.description: A federal appeals court in Washington, D.C. has ruled that National Guard troops can remain in the city for now. That decision comes after a different...

item.title: Trump to address the nation as his popularity dips in the face of economic concerns
item.description: The year-end speech will address his accomplishments so far and look ahead to next year

item.title: A Chinese man who filmed secret footage in Xinjiang risks deportation from the U.S.

item.title: Meta is pausing its dream of sharing Quest’s Horizon OS with third-party headset makers
item.description: The company said that it would revisit opportunities for third-party partnerships in the future.

item.title: What to know about the search for the Brown University shooter
YouTube will stream the Oscars — exclusively — beginning in 2029
item.description: The news highlights YouTube's growing dominance in the television space and a major shift as streaming takes on more live events.

item.title: Jared Isaacman confirmed as next head of NASA
item.description: Isaacman will run the space agency at a time when Trump is trying to both downsize it and task it with returning astronauts to the Moon.

item.title: YouTube to pull music data from Billboard’s charts because it doesn’t like its ranking formula
item.description: YouTube takes its ball and goes home by pulling Billboard's access to its music data.

item.title: Cisco says Chinese hackers are exploiting its customers with a new zero-day
item.description: Cisco said it discovered a Chinese hacking campaign targeting its customers by exploiting a zero-day in some of the company's most popular products.
